newsitem.title: CANADA: Ontario winter wheat plantings seen down 40 pct.
newsitem.headline: Ontario winter wheat plantings seen down 40 pct.

text.p: Winter wheat plantings were likely down 40 percent from last year with 480,000 acres seeded to Ontario's biggest milling wheat crop, an Ontario Wheat Producers' Marketing Board official told Reuters.

"We're guessing that plantings are down by about 40 percent, so we could be in the 480,000 acre range. We get a tonne and a half an acre so you get about 720,000 tonnes," OWPMB secretary manager William McClounie said.
Ontario farmers seeded 800,000 acres to winter wheat last year but a severe outbreak of fusarium headblight downgraded most of the crop to feed grades.
Normally, two-thirds of the crop is exported to the United States or overseas as milling wheat.

"The low plantings are a combination of a wet fall, a late soybean harvest and producers are maybe a little gun shy on replanting wheat because of fusarium. I think a lot of them wanted to get back into crop rotations again," McClounie said.
At 480,000 acres, this would be Ontario's smalled winter wheat crop since the fall of 1991, McClounie said.
